text:
In my experience, one of the most important things to do is to identify the *bottlenecks* in your process/calendar.

Often, that wouldn‚Äôt be writers/the writing process, but something like design. On many teams, design comes from a team (member) which is already owning and working on a number of other things ‚Äî¬†front end design, marketing site/landing pages, creative for display ads, and so on.

If that is the case for your team, you have to be aware and be able to plan around that, so that your calendar does not get blocked because there‚Äôs no free designer to come up with a header image.

If that is the case for your team, you have to be aware and be able to plan around that, so that your calendar does not get blocked because there‚Äôs no free designer to come up with a header image.

text: The grid visualization of topic and funnel depth in <https://www.animalz.co/blog/library-vs-publication/|this article> by <@UQP1YFFBL> always stuck with me bc it‚Äôs such a great way to visualize balance across the calendar. I actually built one in the second tab of an old content calendar when I was starting out except I used Excel and conditional formatting to make it an actual heat map based on the number in each cell. We weren‚Äôt publishing enough to make it useful, so I stopped. but if I ever go somewhere where we‚Äôre publishing 2-4 posts a week I think it could be an interesting planning/reporting visual to return to.

elements.text: The grid visualization of topic and funnel depth in
this article
by

always stuck with me bc it‚Äôs such a great way to visualize balance across the calendar. I actually built one in the second tab of an old content calendar when I was starting out except I used Excel and conditional formatting to make it an actual heat map based on the number in each cell. We weren‚Äôt publishing enough to make it useful, so I stopped. but if I ever go somewhere where we‚Äôre publishing 2-4 posts a week I think it could be an interesting planning/reporting visual to return to.

text: Another one is the importance (at least for me) in having the calendar in something like Airtable vs excel or google sheets. Excel will get the job done but when I switched to Google Tables (cheaper, less functional airtable alternative) it changed the way I was able to visualize my pipeline and I actually have topic and funnel depth as fields so I can sort by those and see the spread across categories (for the reasons mentioned above)

text: Hey all - the company blog I'm building is launching next week (yay) and I want to share (edited) transcripts from our reasonably-popular podcast as blog posts. How can I introduce them as re-published content without people thinking we're being lazy or boring? I'm a one-woman team trying to make a lot with what I've got!

elements.text: Hey all - the company blog I'm building is launching next week (yay) and I want to share (edited) transcripts from our reasonably-popular podcast as blog posts. How can I introduce them as re-published content without people thinking we're being lazy or boring? I'm a one-woman team trying to make a lot with what I've got!

text: Hi y‚Äôall! I‚Äôm trying to make a plan for the site structure of our blog. I was wondering if someone can explain the difference between a hub page (as in hub and spokes) and a category page (not sure if this the right term). What I mean with category page is the page that shows you all articles that fall under a specific topic. Like how Animalz has the different categories to choose from at the top of their blog :point_down: Does a category page function the same way as a hub page in terms of gaining organic traffic? And does it make sense to base your category topics on key word research?

text:
>  How can I introduce them as re-published content without people thinking we‚Äôre being lazy or boring?
People won‚Äôt. Lots of folks look for transcripts instead of audio content, so it‚Äôs already a value-add.

Beyond that, if you‚Äôre doing some editing on top of the transcripts (to isolate big ideas, etc.) it‚Äôs more of a value-add.

I‚Äôd frame it as: ‚ÄúTo help our readers get the most out of our podcast episodes, we‚Äôre publishing edited + cleaned up transcripts along with a few extracted insights.‚Äù

elements.text: How can I introduce them as re-published content without people thinking we‚Äôre being lazy or boring?

People won‚Äôt. Lots of folks look for transcripts instead of audio content, so it‚Äôs already a value-add.

Beyond that, if you‚Äôre doing some editing on top of the transcripts (to isolate big ideas, etc.) it‚Äôs more of a value-add.

I‚Äôd frame it as: ‚ÄúTo help our readers get the most out of our podcast episodes, we‚Äôre publishing edited + cleaned up transcripts along with a few extracted insights.‚Äù

text:
Hey everyone¬†:wave:

Our staging site is being indexed by Google¬†:grimacing:. Seems the HTTP Authentication wasn't set when we migrated the staging and main site from .io to .com¬†:man-facepalming:.

We are adding it back, but will that be enough to stop indexing the pages, or what else do you recommend doing? I've read mixed things about using noindex or nofollow.

.

text:
<@UKAK6J1NY> there are so many good ways to go about this! A few:
‚Ä¢ slice and dice the podcasts by theme so you write posts on one theme with views from multiple leaders
‚Ä¢ feature the thought leader heavily and format it like an ask the expert/go into their background and history more in the intro
‚Ä¢ create a cool infographic based on the learnings from the podcast (since you‚Äôre focused on design)
‚Ä¢ If you go the transcript route, find a few external data points to pepper in throughout so it feels like more info added
Also, I‚Äôd definitely consider turning these podcasts/posts into a lead magnet. I listened to a few of them and there‚Äôs so much valuable info that you could distill into a thought-leader focused ebook!

elements.text: there are so many good ways to go about this! A few:
slice and dice the podcasts by theme so you write posts on one theme with views from multiple leaders
feature the thought leader heavily and format it like an ask the expert/go into their background and history more in the intro
create a cool infographic based on the learnings from the podcast (since you‚Äôre focused on design)
If you go the transcript route, find a few external data points to pepper in throughout so it feels like more info added

Also, I‚Äôd definitely consider turning these podcasts/posts into a lead magnet. I listened to a few of them and there‚Äôs so much valuable info that you could distill into a thought-leader focused ebook!

text:
<@U017WRJTKF1>, one thing I‚Äôve noticed pretty consistently is that content calendars don‚Äôt usually get adhered to all that well, especially at fast-growing companies ‚Äì and that‚Äôs totally OK!

I usually say that people tend to ‚Äúovercalendar and understrategize‚Äù; the calendar should only last for about 4 - 6 weeks but the strategy should be really clear and make it easy to tee up the next batch of content once that time is up.

elements.text:
, one thing I‚Äôve noticed pretty consistently is that content calendars don‚Äôt usually get adhered to all that well, especially at fast-growing companies ‚Äì and that‚Äôs totally OK!

text: Another approach, <@U01LLSRQ57A>, since lead magnets tend not to work for devs but work OK for executives / architects ‚Äì¬†run a few webinars, then turn the most popular into an ebook, and make the gated asset the ebook plus webinar recording?

elements.text: Another approach,

, since lead magnets tend not to work for devs but work OK for executives / architects ‚Äì¬†run a few webinars, then turn the most popular into an ebook, and make the gated asset the ebook plus webinar recording?

text:
I‚Äôve always felt like the distinction between these is a little artificial, <@U01GLCVCT89> ‚Äì they‚Äôre both navigational facets. for example, the Animalz blog is essentially by ‚Äútype‚Äù (very useful to some visitors) and then a more typical hub page would be by ‚Äútopic‚Äù which is more useful for SEO as <@UJG9WTEKG> said.Modern CMSes make it relatively easy to offer both! :)

A really nice approach with auto-generated topic pages, by the way, is to try to weave everything together into a story, and use that as the intro for the page so visitors know how to navigate your content.

elements.text: I‚Äôve always felt like the distinction between these is a little artificial,

‚Äì they‚Äôre both navigational facets. for example, the Animalz blog is essentially by ‚Äútype‚Äù (very useful to some visitors) and then a more typical hub page would be by ‚Äútopic‚Äù which is more useful for SEO as

said.Modern CMSes make it relatively easy to offer both! :)

A really nice approach with auto-generated topic pages, by the way, is to try to weave everything together into a story, and use that as the intro for the page so visitors know how to navigate your content.

text: We're marketing to a developer persona as well and training has been the ticket. We run both paid instructor-led courses as well as a free, on-demand course. It's _amazing._ People absolutely love it, and then when they start using the product, they're more successful!
